required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Efficacy of Virtual Reality During Office Hysteroscopy and Endometrial Biopsy in Subfertility
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Efficacy of Virtual Reality for Acute Pain and Anxiety Management During Outpatient Hysteroscopy and Endometrial Biopsy in Subfertility Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a comparison between the current standard practice of performing a diagnostic hysteroscopy and a relatively recently developed technology that is added to the standard diagnostic hysteroscopy. The aim of the study is to find out whether this newer technology has an advantage for the patient, in the form of anxiety and pain reduction.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This study is a comparison between the current standard practice of performing a diagnostic hysteroscopy and a relatively recently developed technology that is added to the standard diagnostic hysteroscopy. The aim of the study is to find out whether this newer technology has an advantage for the patient, in the form of anxiety and pain reduction.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in pain experience as assessed using visual analog scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1/ baseline pre-procedure 2/ immediately after the procedure (1+2= day of office hysteroscopy) and 3/ 1 week after the procedure
primary_outcome.description: quantified through visual analog scale: from 0.0 to 10.0cm, ranging from 0.0 meaning 'No pain' and 10.0 representing 'worst imaginable pain'.

intervention.intervention_name: Oncomfort, commercially available Virtual Reality headset
intervention.description: Virtual Reality headset, consisting of headphones with smartphone glasses - see oncomfort.com/en, CE approval conform 93/42/EEC and 2007/47/EEC

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- undergoing fertility treatments
- for which outpatient hysteroscopy has been prescribed
- for different possible indications: suspicion of intracavitary pathology, recurrent implantation failure, recurrent early pregnancy loss, â€¦
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Hearing impairments and blindness
2. Motion sickness
3. Any known anatomical characteristics that may make performing the office procedure impossible.
4. The unwillingness of the patient to undergo an office hysteroscopy
5. Denial or withdrawal of informed consent
